1.title: Art of the Silver Screen

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

1.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams introduces the ever-present and all-important element of a great movie: Tension.

2.title: We All Need Another Hero: Universal Stories

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

2.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams explains the Hero's Journey by comparing and contrasting "The Wizard of Oz" and "Star Wars".

3.title: Movie Genre: It's Not What You Think

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

3.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams spells out his multifaceted theory of film genre, identifying the key elements of the twelve Super Genres.

4.title: Genre Layers and Audience Expectations

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

4.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams expands upon his taxonomy by clarifying the difference between Super Genre, Macrogenre and Microgenre, illustrating more than a ten thousand ways to describe a film's genre.

5.title: Popcorn Can Wait: Story Shape and Tension

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

5.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams interprets the story shapes and rhythms of various films, combining his film genre theory with the ever-present need for tension in a film.

6.title: Themes on Screen

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

6.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams proposes a new way to consider theme: a matrix of active/didactic and traditional/non-traditional approaches first identified by Michael Kortlander.

7.title: Paradigm Shift: Citizen Kane and Casablanca

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

7.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams describes the lasting influence of two of history's most revered movies.

8.title: The Language of Visual Storytelling

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

8.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams acquaints the audience with Bruce Block's foundational concepts of how color, line and shape can be utilized to tell more meaningful stories through film.

9.title: Building Screen Space: Blocking and Framing

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

9.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams expounds upon the subconscious impact of blocking and framing by dissecting key scenes from "Good Will Hunting".

10.title: Cutting Room Floor: Powerful Editing

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

10.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams explores the impact that editing has on the tone, pace and theme of a film.

11.title: Sound Design and Acoustic Illusion

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

11.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams introduces the seminal work done by Walter Merch while setting out the tenets of great sound design.

12.title: Setting the Scene: Masterful Set Design

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

12.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams clarifies this importance of set design as it relates to character development within a film.

13.title: Special Effects in the 20th Century

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

13.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams lays out his premise for what makes a good special effects film by recounting the early years of SFX.

14.title: Special Effects in the 21st Century

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

14.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams argues for his two most influential special effects films of the new century while walking us through its first two decades.

15.title: Scoring the Story: Music in Film

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

15.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams sings the praises of musical motifs and leitmotifs while demonstrating how music affects the audience both consciously and subconsciously.

16.title: Color and Light: Elements of Atmosphere

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

16.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams presents color palettes of various films to illustrate the importance of color and light in is telling a visual story.

17.title: Knowing Characters from the Inside Out

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

17.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams lays out the idea of personal, private and public masks that all good characters wear while revealing (and hiding) their true motivation.

18.title: Knowing Characters from the Outside In

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

18.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams uses the various roles played to Morgan Freeman to demonstrate how an actor might read and interpret a screenplay to find the essence of a character.

19.title: Secondary Characters and Supporting Actors

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

19.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams characterizes supporting roles in a film as reflections of the protagonist.

20.title: Star Power: Lead Actors and Their Roles

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

20.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams depicts the various decision points that an actor might make as they consider the changes that a lead character will make through the course of a film.

21.title: Character Relationships and Audience Empathy

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

21.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams suggests that Carl Jung's ideas of archetypes play a pivotal role in how the audience feels about characters - both good and bad.

22.title: Pathways to Great Antagonists

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

22.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams establishes the role of an antagonist by introducing a new way to explore how a story is told: the screenwriter's Pathway.

23.title: Point of View in Script and Screen

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

23.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams delineates one storytelling point of view from another through examples from iconic films such as MASH, A Beautiful Mind and Shawshank Redemption.

24.title: Filmmaker's Voice and Audience Choice

episode of.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (TV Mini-Series 2018)

24.plot: Professor Eric R. Williams proposes yet another unique way to conceptualize storytelling in film: the six Voices that a filmmaker might choose.

imdb.title: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies
akas: How to View and Appreciate Great Movies (United States)
